ul.li1: 1These are also proverbs of Solomon which officials of Hezekiah king of Judah copied:
2The glory of GodOr “gods” conceals things,
ul.li2: but the glory of kings searches out things.
ul.li1: 3As heaven is to height and the earth is to depth,
ul.li2: so is the heartOr “mind” of kings—there is no searching.
ul.li1: 4Remove the dross from silver,
ul.li2: and it will become a vessel for the smith.
ul.li1: 5Remove the wicked before a king,
ul.li2: and his throne will be established in righteousness.Hebrew “in the righteousness”
ul.li1: 6Do not promote yourself before the king,
ul.li2: and in the place of the great ones do not stand.
ul.li1: 7For it is better that he say to you, “Ascend here,”
ul.li2: than he humble you before a noble.
ul.li1: What your eyes have seen,
8do not hastily bring out to court,
ul.li2: forOr “lest” what will you do at its end,
when your neighbor puts you to shame?
ul.li1: 9Argue your argument with your neighbor himself,
ul.li2: the secret of another do not disclose,
ul.li1: 10lest he who hears shame you
ul.li2: and your ill repute will not end.
ul.li1: 11Apples of gold in a setting of silver
ul.li2: is a matter spoken atHebrew “on” its proper time.
ul.li1: 12A ring of gold and an ornament of fine gold
ul.li2: is a rebuke of the wise to the ear of a listener.
ul.li1: 13Like the cold of snow on a dayOr “at a season” of harvest
ul.li2: is a faithful messenger to those who send him,
and the soulOr “life,” or “inner self” of his master is refreshed.Or “returned”
ul.li1: 14Like clouds and wind when there is no rain,
ul.li2: so too is a man who boasts in a gift of deception.
ul.li1: 15With patienceLiterally “With length of face” a ruler may be persuaded,
ul.li2: and a soft tongue will break a bone.Or “strength”
ul.li1: 16If you find honey, eat what is sufficient for you,
ul.li2: lest you have your fill of it and vomit it out.
ul.li1: 17Make your foot scarce in the house of your neighbor,
ul.li2: lest he become weary of you and hate you.
ul.li1: 18Like a club and sword and a sharp arrow
ul.li2: is a man who bears false witness against his neighbor.
ul.li1: 19A bad tooth and a lame foot
ul.li2: is the trust of a faithless person in a timeLiterally “on a day” of trouble.
ul.li1: 20Like one who removes a garment on a cold day, or like vinegar on natron,A mineral salt found on dry lake beds often used as a preservative.
ul.li2: is he who sings songs to a heavy heart.
ul.li1: 21If your enemy is hungry, feed him bread,
ul.li2: and if thirsty, let him drink water.
ul.li1: 22For coals of fire you will heap upon his head,
ul.li2: and Yahweh will reward you.
ul.li1: 23The wind of the north produces rain,
ul.li2: and a backbiting tongue, angry faces.
ul.li1: 24Better to live upon the corner of a roof
ul.li2: than with a womanOr “wife” of contention and in a shared house.
ul.li1: 25Like cold waterHebrew “waters” upon a weary soul,Or “life,” or “inner self”
ul.li2: so too is good news from a distant place.
ul.li1: 26Like a muddied spring or a polluted fountain
ul.li2: is the righteous who gives way before the wicked.
ul.li1: 27To eat much honey is not good,
ul.li2: nor is seeking one’s honorHebrew “their honor” honorable.
ul.li1: 28A breached city where there is no wall
ul.li2: is like a man who has noLiterally “there is no” self-control for his spirit.
